summary: This is an internal email from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) discussing a draft statement in response to a public statement issued by Prince Andrew's UK law firm. The email reveals SDNY's intent to correct what they claim are false assertions regarding confidentiality and the status of Prince Andrew in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.role: Subject of investigation, client of Blackfords LLP
persons.context: The Duke of York, whose UK law firm issued a public statement containing claims that the SDNY email characterizes as false, specifically regarding confidentiality assurances and his status as a 'target' in the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Deceased financier and central figure of the criminal investigation
persons.context: The subject of the criminal investigation into which Prince Andrew's counsel was seeking to clarify his client's status.

connections.description: Prince Andrew is referenced in the context of a criminal investigation into the conduct of Jeffrey Epstein, with his counsel disputing his status as a 'target'.

events.title: Issuance of Prince Andrew's Statement via Blackfords LLP
events.description: A statement was issued by the UK law firm Blackfords LLP on behalf of Prince Andrew regarding communications with the SDNY about interviewing him.

events.title: SDNY Drafts Response to Prince Andrew's Statement
events.description: The SDNY drafts a response refuting claims in Prince Andrew's statement, specifically denying they gave unequivocal confidentiality assurances or communicated that he was not a target.

locations: Southern District of New York (SDNY) - U.S. Attorney's Office
keyFacts: Prince Andrew's UK law firm, Blackfords LLP, issued a public statement claiming the SDNY had given 'unequivocal assurance' that discussions about an interview would remain confidential.
The SDNY explicitly states that Blackfords' claim of confidentiality assurance is false.
The SDNY also refutes the claim that they communicated Prince Andrew was not a 'target' of the criminal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.
The SDNY suggests any misunderstandings could be resolved if Prince Andrew agreed to be interviewed.
